title: Authors and Citation
text: Kai Gu. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Gu K (2023). mcradds: Processing analyzing Vitro Diagnostic Data. https://github.com/kaigu1990/mcradds/, https://kaigu1990.github.io/mcradds/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {mcradds: Processing and analyzing of In Vitro Diagnostic Data},   author = {Kai Gu},   year = {2023},   note = {https://github.com/kaigu1990/mcradds/, https://kaigu1990.github.io/mcradds/}, }

what: Processing and analyzing of In Vitro Diagnostic Data
title: Processing and analyzing of In Vitro Diagnostic Data
text: mcradds R package complement mcr package, contains common solid functions designing, analyzing visualization Vitro Diagnostic trials. methods algorithms refer CLSI recommendations NMPA guidelines. package provides series typical functionality, shown : Regression methods method comparison Bland-Altman analysis plots numeric data Outlier detection, including 4E method EP09A2 ESD method EP09A3 Correlation, adding hypothesis test confidence interval Estimating bias medical decision level Computing Reference Range/Interval CLSI EP28-A3 NMPA guideline ROC/AUC non-inferiority trials Diagnostic accuracy criteria Precision analysis Descriptive statistics, proportion/ratios

title: Processing and analyzing of In Vitro Diagnostic Data
text: can install development version GitHub : See package vignettes browseVignettes(package = "mcradds") usage package.

title: BAsummary class — BAsummary-class
text: BAsummary class used display BlandAltman analysis outliers.

title: BAsummary class — BAsummary-class
BAsummary class — BAsummary-class
text: data (data.frame) stores raw data input. stat (list) contains several statistics numeric data.

title: BAsummary class — BAsummary-class
text: object class BAsummary.

title: BAsummary class — BAsummary-class
text: slots data data outlier

title: EDS Test for Outliers — ESD_test
text: Perform Rosner's generalized extreme Studentized deviate (ESD) test, assumes distribution normal (Gaussian), can used number outliers unknown, becomes robust number samples increases.

title: EDS Test for Outliers — ESD_test
EDS Test for Outliers — ESD_test
text: x (numeric) vector observations can difference Bland-Altman analysis. Normally relative difference preferred IVD trials. Missing(NA) allowed removed. must least 10 available observations x. alpha (numeric) type--risk, \(\alpha\). h (integer) positive integer indicating number suspected outliers. argument h must 1 n-2 n denotes number available values x. default value h = 5.

title: EDS Test for Outliers — ESD_test
text: list class containing results ESD test. stat data frame contains several statistics ESD test includes index(), Mean, SD, raw data(x), location(Obs) x, ESD statistics(ESDi), Lambda Outliers(TRUE FALSE). ord vector order index outliers equal Obs stat data frame.

title: EDS Test for Outliers — ESD_test
text: algorithm determining number outliers follows: Compare ESDi Lambda. ESDi > Lambda observations regards outliers. order index corresponds available x data removed missing (NA) value. compare ESD(h) ESD(h+1) equal, h+1 ESD values shown. identical, can regarded outliers.

title: EDS Test for Outliers — ESD_test
text: CLSI EP09A3 Appendix B. Detecting Aberrant Results (Outliers).

title: EDS Test for Outliers — ESD_test

MCTab class — MCTab-class

text: object class MCTab.

title: Calculate statistics for Bland-Altman — blandAltman
text: Calculate Bland-Altman related statistics specific difference type, difference, limited agreement confidence interval. outlier detecting function graphic function get difference result .

title: Calculate statistics for Bland-Altman — blandAltman
code: blandAltman(x, y, sid = NULL, type1 = 3, type2 = 5, conf.level = 0.95)

title: Calculate statistics for Bland-Altman — blandAltman
text: x (numeric) reference method. y (numeric) test method. sid (numeric string) sample id. type1 (integer) specifying specific difference absolute difference, default 3. type2 (integer) specifying specific difference relative difference, default 5. conf.level (numeric) significance level two side, default 0.95.

title: Calculate statistics for Bland-Altman — blandAltman
text: object BAsummary class contains BlandAltman analysis. data data frame contains raw data input. stat list contains summary table (tab) Bland-Altman analysis, vector (absolute_diff) absolute difference vector (relative_diff) relative difference.

title: Calculate statistics for Bland-Altman — blandAltman
code: data("platelet") blandAltman(x = platelet$Comparative, y = platelet$Candidate) #>                             Absolute.difference Relative.difference #> N                                           120                 120 #> Mean (SD)                        7.330 (15.990)      0.064 ( 0.145) #> Median                                    6.350               0.055 #> Q1, Q3                         ( 0.150, 15.750)    ( 0.001,  0.118) #> Min, Max                      (-47.800, 42.100)    (-0.412,  0.667) #> Limit of Agreement            (-24.011, 38.671)    (-0.220,  0.347) #> Confidence Interval of Mean    ( 4.469, 10.191)    ( 0.038,  0.089)  # with sample id as input sid blandAltman(x = platelet$Comparative, y = platelet$Candidate, sid = platelet$Sample) #>                             Absolute.difference Relative.difference #> N                                           120                 120 #> Mean (SD)                        7.330 (15.990)      0.064 ( 0.145) #> Median                                    6.350               0.055 #> Q1, Q3                         ( 0.150, 15.750)    ( 0.001,  0.118) #> Min, Max                      (-47.800, 42.100)    (-0.412,  0.667) #> Limit of Agreement            (-24.011, 38.671)    (-0.220,  0.347) #> Confidence Interval of Mean    ( 4.469, 10.191)    ( 0.038,  0.089)

what: Systematical Bias Between Reference Method and Test Method — calcBias
title: Systematical Bias Between Reference Method and Test Method — calcBias
text: copy mcr::calcBias mcr package

title: Systematical Bias Between Reference Method and Test Method — calcBias
Systematical Bias Between Reference Method and Test Method — calcBias
text: ... Arguments passed mcr::calcBias .Object object class "MCResult".

title: Systematical Bias Between Reference Method and Test Method — calcBias
text: Bis corresponding confidence interval specific medical decision levels (x.levels).

title: Systematical Bias Between Reference Method and Test Method — calcBias
code: data(platelet) fit <- mcreg(   x = platelet$Comparative, y = platelet$Candidate,   method.reg = "Deming", method.ci = "jackknife" ) #> Jackknife based calculation of standard error and confidence intervals according to Linnet's method. calcBias(fit, x.levels = c(30, 200)) #>    Level     Bias       SE      LCI      UCI #> X1    30 4.724429 1.378232 1.995155 7.453704 #> X2   200 6.926183 1.288534 4.374535 9.477832 calcBias(fit, x.levels = c(30, 200), type = "proportional") #>    Level Prop.bias(%)        SE      LCI       UCI #> X1    30    15.748098 4.5941062 6.650517 24.845679 #> X2   200     3.463092 0.6442671 2.187267  4.738916 calcBias(fit, x.levels = c(30, 200), type = "proportional", percent = FALSE) #>    Level  Prop.bias          SE        LCI        UCI #> X1    30 0.15748098 0.045941062 0.06650517 0.24845679 #> X2   200 0.03463092 0.006442671 0.02187267 0.04738916

Creates Contingency Table — diagTab
text: Creates 2x2 contingency table data frame matrix qualitative performance downstream analysis.

title: Creates Contingency Table — diagTab
code: diagTab(formula = ~., data, ..., rlevels = NULL, clevels = NULL)

title: Creates Contingency Table — diagTab
text: formula (numeric) formula object cross-classifying variables (separated +) right hand side. row name contingency represented variable left + sign, col name represented variable right. data (data.frame matrix) data frame matrix. ... arguments passed xtabs(). rlevels (vector) character vector known levels row name contingency table. clevels (vector) character vector known levels col name contingency table.

title: Creates Contingency Table — diagTab
text: object matrix contains 2x2 contingency table.

title: Creates Contingency Table — diagTab
code: data("qualData") qualData %>% diagTab(formula = ~ CandidateN + ComparativeN) #>  Contingency Table:  #>  #>   candidate has 2 levels: 0 1 #>   comparative has 2 levels: 0 1  #>  #>           ComparativeN #> CandidateN  0   1 #>          0 54  16 #>          1  8 122 qualData %>%   diagTab(     formula = ~ CandidateN + ComparativeN,     rlevels = c(1, 0), clevels = c(1, 0)   ) #>  Contingency Table:  #>  #>   candidate has 2 levels: 1 0 #>   comparative has 2 levels: 1 0  #>  #>           ComparativeN #> CandidateN   1  0 #>          1 122  8 #>          0  16 54

what: Summary Method for MCTab Objects — getAccuracy
title: Summary Method for MCTab Objects — getAccuracy
text: Provides concise summary content MCTab objects. Computes sensitivity, specificity, positive negative predictive values positive negative likelihood ratios diagnostic test reference/gold standard. Computes positive negative percent agreement, overall percent agreement new test evaluated comparison non-reference standard.

title: Summary Method for MCTab Objects — getAccuracy
code: getAccuracy(object, ...)  # S4 method for MCTab getAccuracy(   object,   withref = TRUE,   method = c("wilson", "wald", "clopper-pearson"),   alpha = 0.05,   digits = 4,   ... )

title: Summary Method for MCTab Objects — getAccuracy
text: object (MCTab) input diagTab function create 2x2 contingency table. ... arguments passed DescTools::BinomCI. withref (logical) weather comparison test reference/gold standard . method (string) string specifying method use. Default wilson. Options can wilson, wald clopper-pearson, see DescTools::BinomCI. alpha (numeric) type--risk, \(\alpha\). digits (integer) desired number digits. Default 4.

title: Summary Method for MCTab Objects — getAccuracy
text: data frame contains qualitative diagnostic accuracy criteria three columns estimated value confidence interval. sens: Sensitivity refers often test positive condition interest present. spec: Specificity refers often test negative condition interest absent. ppv: Positive predictive value refers percentage subjects positive test result target condition. npv: Negative predictive value refers percentage subjects negative test result target condition. plr: Positive likelihood ratio refers probability true positive rate divided false negative rate. nlr: Negative likelihood ratio refers probability false positive rate divided true negative rate. ppa: Positive percent agreement, equals sensitivity candidate method evaluated comparison comparative method, reference/gold standard. npa: Negative percent agreement, equals specificity candidate method evaluated comparison comparative method, reference/gold standard.

title: Summary Method for MCTab Objects — getAccuracy
code: tab <- qualData %>%   diagTab(     formula = ~ CandidateN + ComparativeN,     rlevels = c(1, 0), clevels = c(1, 0)   ) getAccuracy(tab, method = "wilson") #>         EST LowerCI UpperCI #> sens 0.8841  0.8200  0.9274 #> spec 0.8710  0.7655  0.9331 #> ppv  0.9385  0.8833  0.9685 #> npv  0.7714  0.6605  0.8541 #> plr  6.8514  3.5785 13.1181 #> nlr  0.1331  0.0832  0.2131 getAccuracy(tab, method = "wilson", withref = FALSE) #>        EST LowerCI UpperCI #> ppa 0.8841  0.8200  0.9274 #> npa 0.8710  0.7655  0.9331 #> opa 0.8800  0.8277  0.9180

title: Get Regression Coefficients — getCoefficients
text: copy mcr::getCoefficients mcr package

title: Get Regression Coefficients — getCoefficients
Get Regression Coefficients — getCoefficients
text: ... Arguments passed mcr::getCoefficients .Object object class "MCResult".

title: Get Regression Coefficients — getCoefficients
code: data(platelet) fit <- mcreg(   x = platelet$Comparative, y = platelet$Candidate,   method.reg = "Deming", method.ci = "jackknife" ) #> Jackknife based calculation of standard error and confidence intervals according to Linnet's method. getCoefficients(fit) #>                EST          SE       LCI      UCI #> Intercept 4.335885 1.568968372 1.2289002 7.442869 #> Slope     1.012951 0.009308835 0.9945175 1.031386

what: Detect Outliers From BAsummary Object — getOutlier
title: Detect Outliers From BAsummary Object — getOutlier
text: Detect potential outliers absolute relative differences BAsummary object 4E ESD method.

title: Detect Outliers From BAsummary Object — getOutlier
code: getOutlier(object, ...)  # S4 method for BAsummary getOutlier(   object,   method = c("ESD", "4E"),   difference = c("abs", "rel"),   alpha = 0.05,   h = 5 )

title: Detect Outliers From BAsummary Object — getOutlier
text: object (BAsummary) input blandAltman function generate Bland-Altman analysis result contains absolute relative differences. ... additional arguments. method (string) string specifying method use. Default ESD. difference (string) string specifying difference type use ESD method. Default abs means absolute difference, rel relative difference. alpha (numeric) type--risk. used method defined ESD. h (integer) positive integer indicating number suspected outliers. used method defined ESD.

title: Detect Outliers From BAsummary Object — getOutlier
text: list contains statistics results (stat), outliers' ord id (ord), sample id (sid), matrix outliers (outmat) matrix without outliers (rmmat).

title: Detect Outliers From BAsummary Object — getOutlier
text: Bland-Altman analysis used input data regardless 4E ESD method necessary determine absolute relative differences beforehand. 4E method, absolute relative differences required define, bias exceeds 4 fold absolute relative differences. However ESD method, one necessary (latter recommended), bias needs meet ESD test.

title: Detect Outliers From BAsummary Object — getOutlier

what: Compute the difference for Bland-Altman — h_difference
title: Compute the difference for Bland-Altman — h_difference
text: Helper function computes difference specific type.

title: Compute the difference for Bland-Altman — h_difference
Compute the difference for Bland-Altman — h_difference
text: x (numeric) reference method. y (numeric) test method. type (integer) integer specifying specific difference Bland-Altman (default 3). Possible choices : 1 - difference X vs. Y-X (absolute differences). 2 - difference X vs. (Y-X)/X (relative differences). 3 - difference 0.5*(X+Y) vs. Y-X (absolute differences). 4 - difference 0.5*(X+Y) vs. (Y-X)/X (relative differences). 5 - difference 0.5*(X+Y) vs. (Y-X)/(0.5*(X+Y)) (relative differences).

title: Compute the difference for Bland-Altman — h_difference
text: matrix contains x y measurement data corresponding difference.

title: Compute the difference for Bland-Altman — h_difference

mcradss Package — mcradds-package
text: mcradss facilitates analyzing reporting IVD trials.

title: mcradss Package — mcradds-package
text: Maintainer: Kai Gu gukai1212@163.com

what: Comparison of Two Measurement Methods Using Regression Analysis — mcreg
title: Comparison of Two Measurement Methods Using Regression Analysis — mcreg
text: copy mcr::mcreg mcr package

title: Comparison of Two Measurement Methods Using Regression Analysis — mcreg
Comparison of Two Measurement Methods Using Regression Analysis — mcreg
text: ... Arguments passed mcr::mcreg x measurement values reference method, two column matrix. y measurement values test method. error.ratio ratio squared measurement errors reference  test method, necessary Deming regression (Default 1). alpha value specifying 100(1-alpha)% confidence level confidence intervals (Default 0.05). mref.name name reference method (Default "Method1"). mtest.name name test Method (Default "Method2"). sample.names names cases (Default "S##"). method.reg regression method.  possible choose five regression methods:  "LinReg" - ordinary least square regression."WLinReg" - weighted ordinary least square regression."Deming" - Deming regression."WDeming" - weighted Deming regression."TS" - Theil-Sen regression."PBequi" - equivariant Passing-Bablok regression."PaBa" - Passing-Bablok regression."PaBaLarge" - approximative Passing-Bablok regression large datasets, operating NBins classes constant slope angle slope                      classified instead building complete triangular matrix N*N/2 slopes. method.ci method confidence interval calculation. function  contains four basic methods calculation confidence intervals regression coefficients.  "analytical" - parametric method."jackknife" - leave one resampling."bootstrap" - ordinary non-parametric bootstrap resampling."nested bootstrap" - ordinary non-parametric bootstrap resampling. method.bootstrap.ci bootstrap based confidence interval estimation method. nsamples number bootstrap samples. nnested number nested bootstrap samples. rng.seed integer number sets random number generator seed bootstrap sampling. set NULL currently R session used RNG setting used. rng.kind type random number generator bootstrap sampling. used rng.seed specified, see set.seed details. iter.max maximum number iterations weighted Deming iterative algorithm. threshold numerical tolerance weighted Deming iterative algorithm convergence. na.rm remove measurement pairs contain missing values (Default FALSE). NBins number bins used 'reg.method="PaBaLarge"' classify slope one 'NBins' bins covering range slopes slope.measure angular measure pairwise slopes used exact PaBa regression (see details)."radian" - data sets even sample numbers median slope calculated average two central slope angles."tangent" - data sets even sample numbers median slope calculated average two central slopes (tan(angle)). methodlarge Boolean. parameter applies regmethod="PBequi" "TS". TRUE, quasilinear algorithm used.  FALSE, quadratic algorithm used faster less several hundred data pairs.

title: Comparison of Two Measurement Methods Using Regression Analysis — mcreg
text: regression fit model.

title: Comparison of Two Measurement Methods Using Regression Analysis — mcreg
code: data(platelet) fit <- mcreg(   x = platelet$Comparative, y = platelet$Candidate,   method.reg = "Deming", method.ci = "jackknife" ) #> Jackknife based calculation of standard error and confidence intervals according to Linnet's method. printSummary(fit) #>  #>  #> ------------------------------------------ #>  #> Reference method: Method1 #> Test method:     Method2 #> Number of data points: 120 #>  #> ------------------------------------------ #>  #> The confidence intervals are calculated with jackknife (Linnet's) method. #> Confidence level: 95% #> Error ratio: 1 #>  #> ------------------------------------------ #>  #> DEMING REGRESSION FIT: #>  #>                EST          SE       LCI      UCI #> Intercept 4.335885 1.568968372 1.2289002 7.442869 #> Slope     1.012951 0.009308835 0.9945175 1.031386 #>  #>  #> ------------------------------------------ #>  #> JACKKNIFE SUMMARY #>  #>                EST Jack.Mean          Bias     Jack.SE #> Intercept 4.335885  4.336377  4.918148e-04 1.568968372 #> Slope     1.012951  1.012950 -1.876312e-06 0.009308835 #> NULL getCoefficients(fit) #>                EST          SE       LCI      UCI #> Intercept 4.335885 1.568968372 1.2289002 7.442869 #> Slope     1.012951 0.009308835 0.9945175 1.031386

what: Hypothesis test for Pearson correlation coefficient — pearsonTest
title: Hypothesis test for Pearson correlation coefficient — pearsonTest
text: Adjust cor.test function can define specific H0 per request, based Fisher's Z transformation correlation.

title: Hypothesis test for Pearson correlation coefficient — pearsonTest
code: pearsonTest(   x,   y,   h0 = 0,   conf.level = 0.95,   alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),   ... )

title: Hypothesis test for Pearson correlation coefficient — pearsonTest
text: x (numeric) one measurement. y (numeric) another measurement. h0 (numeric) specified hypothesized value difference two correlations, default 0. conf.level (numeric) significance level returned confidence interval hypothesis. alternative (string) string specifying alternative hypothesis, must one "two.sided" (default), "greater" "less". ... arguments passed cor.test().

title: Hypothesis test for Pearson correlation coefficient — pearsonTest
text: named vector contains correlation coefficient (cor), confidence interval(lowerci upperci), Z statistic (Z) p-value (pval)

title: Hypothesis test for Pearson correlation coefficient — pearsonTest
text: NCSS correlation document

title: Hypothesis test for Pearson correlation coefficient — pearsonTest

code: size_one_prop(p1 = 0.95, p0 = 0.9, alpha = 0.05, power = 0.8) #>  #>  Sample size determination for one Proportion  #>  #>  Call: size_one_prop(p1 = 0.95, p0 = 0.9, alpha = 0.05, power = 0.8) #>  #>    optimal sample size: n = 239  #>  #>    p1:0.95 p0:0.9 alpha:0.05 power:0.8 alternative:two.sided size_ci_corr(r = 0.9, lr = 0.85, alpha = 0.025, alternative = "greater") #>  #>  Sample size determination for a Given Lower Confidence Interval of Pearson's Correlation  #>  #>  Call: size_ci_corr(r = 0.9, lr = 0.85, alpha = 0.025, alternative = "greater") #>  #>    optimal sample size: n = 86  #>  #>    r:0.9 lr:0.85 alpha:0.025 interval:c(10, 1e+05) tol:1e-05 alternative:greater qualData %>% diagTab(formula = ~ CandidateN + ComparativeN) #>  Contingency Table:  #>  #>   candidate has 2 levels: 0 1 #>   comparative has 2 levels: 0 1  #>  #>           ComparativeN #> CandidateN  0   1 #>          0 54  16 #>          1  8 122 data("creatinine", package = "mcr") blandAltman(x = creatinine$serum.crea, y = creatinine$plasma.crea) #>                             Absolute.difference Relative.difference #> N                                           108                 108 #> Mean (SD)                        0.008 ( 0.156)     -0.001 ( 0.140) #> Median                                   -0.020              -0.017 #> Q1, Q3                         (-0.090,  0.112)    (-0.097,  0.080) #> Min, Max                       (-0.330,  0.490)    (-0.305,  0.464) #> Limit of Agreement             (-0.299,  0.314)    (-0.275,  0.273) #> Confidence Interval of Mean    (-0.022,  0.037)    (-0.027,  0.026)

text: r (numeric) expected correlation coefficient evaluated assay. lr (numeric) acceptable correlation coefficient evaluated assay. alpha (numeric) type--risk, \(\alpha\). interval (numeric) numeric vector containing end-points interval searched root(sample size). defaults set c(1, 100000). tol (numeric) tolerance searching root(sample size). alternative (string) string specifying alternative hypothesis, must one "two.sided" (default), "greater" "less".

what: Sample size determination for testing a given lower confidence interval of one proportion — size_ci_one_prop
title: Sample size determination for testing a given lower confidence interval of one proportion — size_ci_one_prop
text: function performs sample size computation testing given lower confidence interval one proportion using Simple Asymptotic(Wald), Wilson score, clopper-pearson methods.

title: Sample size determination for testing a given lower confidence interval of one proportion — size_ci_one_prop
code: size_ci_one_prop(   p,   lr,   alpha = 0.05,   interval = c(1, 1e+05),   tol = 1e-05,   alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),   method = c("simple-asymptotic", "wilson", "wald", "clopper-pearson") )

title: Sample size determination for testing a given lower confidence interval of one proportion — size_ci_one_prop
text: p (numeric) expected criteria evaluated assay. lr (numeric) acceptable criteria evaluated assay. alpha (numeric) type--risk, \(\alpha\). interval (numeric) numeric vector containing end-points interval searched root(sample size). defaults set c(1, 100000). tol (numeric) tolerance searching root(sample size). alternative (string) string specifying alternative hypothesis, must one "two.sided" (default), "greater" "less". method (string) string specifying method use. Simple Asymptotic default, equal Wald. Options can "wilson", "clopper-pearson" method, see DescTools::BinomCIn

title: Sample size determination for testing a given lower confidence interval of one proportion — size_ci_one_prop
text: object size class contains sample size relevant parameters.

title: Sample size determination for testing a given lower confidence interval of one proportion — size_ci_one_prop
text: Newcombe, R. G. 1998. 'Two-Sided Confidence Intervals Single Proportion: Comparison Seven Methods.' Statistics Medicine, 17, pp. 857-872.

title: Sample size determination for testing a given lower confidence interval of one proportion — size_ci_one_prop
code: size_ci_one_prop(p = 0.85, lr = 0.8, alpha = 0.05, method = "wilson") #>  #>  Sample size determination for a Given Lower Confidence Interval  #>  #>  Call: size_ci_one_prop(p = 0.85, lr = 0.8, alpha = 0.05, method = "wilson") #>  #>    optimal sample size: n = 246  #>  #>    p:0.85 lr:0.8 alpha:0.05 interval:c(1, 1e+05) tol:1e-05 alternative:two.sided method:wilson size_ci_one_prop(p = 0.85, lr = 0.8, alpha = 0.05, method = "simple-asymptotic") #>  #>  Sample size determination for a Given Lower Confidence Interval  #>  #>  Call: size_ci_one_prop(p = 0.85, lr = 0.8, alpha = 0.05, method = "simple-asymptotic") #>  #>    optimal sample size: n = 196  #>  #>    p:0.85 lr:0.8 alpha:0.05 interval:c(1, 1e+05) tol:1e-05 alternative:two.sided method:simple-asymptotic size_ci_one_prop(p = 0.85, lr = 0.8, alpha = 0.05, method = "wald") #>  #>  Sample size determination for a Given Lower Confidence Interval  #>  #>  Call: size_ci_one_prop(p = 0.85, lr = 0.8, alpha = 0.05, method = "wald") #>  #>    optimal sample size: n = 196  #>  #>    p:0.85 lr:0.8 alpha:0.05 interval:c(1, 1e+05) tol:1e-05 alternative:two.sided method:wald

what: Sample size determination for testing Pearson's correlation — size_corr
title: Sample size determination for testing Pearson's correlation — size_corr
text: function performs sample size computation testing Pearson's correlation, using uses Fisher's classic z-transformation normalize distribution Pearson's correlation coefficient.

title: Sample size determination for testing Pearson's correlation — size_corr
code: size_corr(   r1,   r0,   alpha = 0.05,   power = 0.8,   alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater") )

title: Sample size determination for testing Pearson's correlation — size_corr
text: r1 (numeric) expected correlation coefficient evaluated assay. r0 (numeric) acceptable correlation coefficient evaluated assay. alpha (numeric) type--risk, \(\alpha\). power (numeric) Power test, equal 1 minus type-II-risk (\(\beta\)). alternative (string) string specifying alternative hypothesis, must one "two.sided" (default), "greater" "less".

title: Sample size determination for testing Pearson's correlation — size_corr
text: object size class contains sample size relevant parameters.

what: Hypothesis test for Spearman correlation coefficient — spearmanTest
title: Hypothesis test for Spearman correlation coefficient — spearmanTest
text: Providing confidence interval Spearman's rank correlation Bootstrap, define specific H0 per request, based Fisher's Z transformation correlation variance recommended Bonett Wright (2000), Pearson's.

title: Hypothesis test for Spearman correlation coefficient — spearmanTest
code: spearmanTest(   x,   y,   h0 = 0,   conf.level = 0.95,   alternative = c("two.sided", "less", "greater"),   nrep = 1000,   rng.seed = NULL,   ... )

title: Hypothesis test for Spearman correlation coefficient — spearmanTest
text: x (numeric) one measurement. y (numeric) another measurement. h0 (numeric) specified hypothesized value difference two correlations, default 0. conf.level (numeric) significance level returned confidence interval hypothesis. alternative (string) string specifying alternative hypothesis, must one "two.sided" (default), "greater" "less". nrep (integer) number replicates bootstrapping, default 1000. rng.seed (integer) number random number generator seed bootstrap sampling. set NULL currently R session used RNG setting used. ... arguments passed cor.test().

title: Hypothesis test for Spearman correlation coefficient — spearmanTest
text: named vector contains correlation coefficient (cor), confidence interval(lowerci upperci), Z statistic (Z) p-value (pval)

title: Hypothesis test for Spearman correlation coefficient — spearmanTest
text: NCSS correlation document

title: Hypothesis test for Spearman correlation coefficient — spearmanTest

text: First release mcradds package, contains basic quantitative qualitative performance methods functions shown .

title: mcradds 0.1.0
text: size_one_prop size_ci_one_prop sample size qualitative trials, size_corr size_ci_corr quantitative trails.

title: mcradds 0.1.0
text: SampleSize, MCTab BAsummary classes show method. platelet qualData data sets example testing use.

title: mcradds 0.1.0
text: diagTab function get 2x2 contingency table, getAccuracy method compute qualitative diagnostic accuracy criteria. blandAltman function calculate statistics Bland-Altman, getOutlier method detect potential outliers. pearsonTest spearmanTest, efficient functions compute confidence interval hypothesis test. mcreg calcBias methods mcr package wrapped regression analysis.
